TEN LECTURES
TO BE GIVEN
BYWILLOUGHBY

Ten lectures on "The Practice and
Procedure of Congress" will be presented by Dr. W. F. Willoughby,
noted political scientist, this fall, it
was announced by Dr. Joseph S.
Ames president of the Johns Hopkins University, under the James
Schouler Lectureship. The exact
dates of the lectures are as yet unannounced.
Dr. Willoughby, the twin brother
.of Dr. W. W. Willoughby, member
of the Johns Hopkins faculty, received his degrees at the J. H. U.
Since 1916 he has been the director
of the Institute for Government Research, of Princeton, the university
at which he was professor of jurisprudence and politics from 1912 to
Dr. Willoughby has also
1917.
in public administralecturer
been a
tion at the Hopkins since 1919.
Was At Harvard, Hopkins

Several times he represented the
U. S. Department of Labor at international congresses and to make labor investigations in Europe. For
two years, 1914 to 1916, he acted as
constitutional adviser to the Chinese
Republic. From 1890 to 1901 he
was employed as an expert by the
Department of Labor in Washington. In 1901 he became a lecturer
in economics at the Hopkins and at
Harvard.
Dr. Willoughby was a member of
the President's committee on economy and efficiency in 1911-12, before he joined the Princeton faculty.
Before his appointment to the committee he was assistant director of
the United States Census for two
years.

ELECTRICAL SHOCKS
TOPIC OF ADDRESS BY
DR. KOUWENHOVEN
Will Lecture At Assembly
On Researches In Electrical Charges
COOPERATES WITH
DR. LANGWORTHY
Finds Fat Animals Withstand
Charges Better Than
Others
Dr. William B. Kouwenhoven,
professor of electrical engineering
and assistant dean of the School of
Engineering of the Johns Hopkins
University, will lecture to the Hopkins lowerclassmen on electrical
shocks at the Assembly this Thursday noon.
He will discuss the researches
which he and Dr. 0. R. Langworthy, associate in neurology at
the Medical School, have been coilducting for the past few years.
Fat Rats Withstand Shock

Professor Kouwenhoven has
found that fat animals seem to be
more capable of withstanding electric charges. He attributes this to
the fact that there is less current
concentrated in plump animals and
not because of the resistance of the
fat.
Many scientific papers and monographs have been written on this
topic by the assistant dean.

Today marks the opening of the
third annual campaign of the Hopkins Y. M. C. A. to raise $1200
from the student body at the University. An organization of fiftythree men was formed last night on
the same order as those used in the
past two successful campaigns, with
Walter A. Glass as generalissimo.
The Hopkins Association's budget calls for $1825 to cover expenses
directly traceable to the use of Levering Hall by students and including such items as operating expenses of the Hall, radio repairs, maintenance of the rooming bureau, publication of the Handbook, and similar things. Six hundred and twenty-five dollars of this is covered
by the Y's share of the Student Activities funds. The remainder must
be raised by the students.

Glass Heads Committee

The organization under Glass
consists of four divisions of three
teams each under the team leadership of Cyrus Young, John Weeks,
Keith Conning and Richard Feise.
Each team consists of a captain and
three men. In this way, it is hoped
that every man on the campus will
be solicited.

Overseas Institute
Announces Offer Of
25 Full Scholarships
serving Students
Announcement has recently been
made by the Overseas Educational
Institute of Hanover, N. H., of
twenty-five full scholarships that it
is offering to deserving students for
study in France, Germany, and in
Switzerland.
A new development in modern
educational organization is revealed
in the program of the Institute, a
school which, in addition to preparing for junior college and college
entrance requirements, presents the
opportunity of travel and association
with European universities and the
cultural advantages to be derived
therefrom.
Visits France And Germany

The institute provides its entire
year's program of travel and study
abroad at a cost approximating an
average year at a prepartory school
or college, and through the medium
of an experienced faculty, offers a
high standard of scholarship.

Council's Duties

Aim At Better June Week;
Suggestions
Wanted
June Week activities made a definite start yesterday when Jack Henderson chairman, appointed Jerome
Toohey, president of the Cotillion
Board; Charles Davis, business
manager of both The Hullabaloo
and the Barnstormers; and Caleb
Kelly, president of the last year's
Junior Class and 1931-32 basketball
captain, to the June Week Committee for this year. These men, at
the request of William Reid, president of the Senior Class, are to prepare a budget for the Week. Reid,
it was announced, will be an exofficio member of the committee.
Hopes To Give Fine Week

"Other men may be appointed at
a later date if the need for more
members becomes apparent," Henderson said yesterday. "I hope,
too, to give Hopkins the finest Julie
Week it has ever had with a material reduction in the cost of tickets.
Any suggestions for the betterment
of June Week, any new events or
changes in the program that will aid
in making it a bigger and better
event will certainly be welcomed by
the committee."
In regard to the additional member of the committee, Henderson
pointed out, a member of the Junior
Class is to be appointed soon by the
president of the Class, Don Kelly,
and that it has been a custom in past
years to select a member of the Cotillion Board to fill that place.

arises: How, then, can it be determined
just how many students are present at

We want Student Council to ACT at

cannot be permitted to slide by into the

Hopkins Swimmi-,g- team thirty-one
candidates turned out. The purpose
of the gathering was to discuss the
plans for the coming year.
Among those back from last year
are Captain William Reid, holder
of the Indoor and Outdoor South
Atlantic Low Board Diving Championship; Edward Sadtler, Johns
Hopkins breast stroke champion;
Ted Stern, Nicholas Camara-Peon,
Charles Bahlke, and Arthur Denues.
All students interested in swimming are urged to come out for the
team.

Running true to form, the favorites have advanced without any major upset. The closest to an upset
was the Needle-Tillman match.
Needle, seeded fourth, finally won,
after three gruelling sets, 8-6, 3-6,
6-2.
The default of Victor Lebow,
seeded third, to D. E. Cohen removes one of the most potent racquet wielders from the field.
With good weather, the latter
part of the week should find some
classy tennis as the late rounds get
under progress.

Mount Washington, and Forest
Park. These clubs, along with
Walbrook, champions last season,
formed the Iceland Hockey League
which operated at Carlin's Rink the
previous year.
The new organization will play
its games at a new rink, the Sports
Centre, which is being erected at
North Avenue and Charles Street.
Mr. Gresham Poe has been elected
president of the new league, and
will control all operations for the
coming season.
The new Sports Centre is located
in the same building where ice
hockey was introduced into this section of the United States several
years ago. It is a striking coincidence that this same building should
be the scene of present-day and improved ice hockey matches.

Cross Country Team
Practices At St. Johns
The cross-country varsity, including Holzman, Packard, Furst, King,
Lewis, Clark, Brown, Emmert, and
Cornman, travelled down to Annapolis on Monday, November 7,
to acquaint themselves with the St.
John's course.
This year the encounter with St.
John's will be especially interesting
because the last two meets were
each decided by a difference of one
point in the score. Furthermore,
a new system of scoring is to be put
into effect for the first time this
year in the St. John's meet by which
men who come in sixth and seventh
influence the count for their team.
The junior varsity meets Poly at
Homewood on Wednesday for its
second meet of the season. The
men who will run are Fryer, Onderdonk, Milstone, Loiseaux, Miller, Emmert, Larrick, and Davies.

TEN LECTURES
TO BE GIVEN
BYWILLOUGHBY

Ten lectures on "The Practice and
Procedure of Congress" will be presented by Dr. W. F. Willoughby,
noted political scientist, this fall, it
was announced by Dr. Joseph S.
Ames president of the Johns Hopkins University, under the James
Schouler Lectureship. The exact
dates of the lectures are as yet unannounced.
Dr. Willoughby, the twin brother
.of Dr. W. W. Willoughby, member
of the Johns Hopkins faculty, received his degrees at the J. H. U.
Since 1916 he has been the director
of the Institute for Government Research, of Princeton, the university
at which he was professor of jurisprudence and politics from 1912 to
Dr. Willoughby has also
1917.
in public administralecturer
been a
tion at the Hopkins since 1919.
Was At Harvard, Hopkins

Several times he represented the
U. S. Department of Labor at international congresses and to make labor investigations in Europe. For
two years, 1914 to 1916, he acted as
constitutional adviser to the Chinese
Republic. From 1890 to 1901 he
was employed as an expert by the
Department of Labor in Washington. In 1901 he became a lecturer
in economics at the Hopkins and at
Harvard.
Dr. Willoughby was a member of
the President's committee on economy and efficiency in 1911-12, before he joined the Princeton faculty.
Before his appointment to the committee he was assistant director of
the United States Census for two
years.

ELECTRICAL SHOCKS
TOPIC OF ADDRESS BY
DR. KOUWENHOVEN
Will Lecture At Assembly
On Researches In Electrical Charges
COOPERATES WITH
DR. LANGWORTHY
Finds Fat Animals Withstand
Charges Better Than
Others
Dr. William B. Kouwenhoven,
professor of electrical engineering
and assistant dean of the School of
Engineering of the Johns Hopkins
University, will lecture to the Hopkins lowerclassmen on electrical
shocks at the Assembly this Thursday noon.
He will discuss the researches
which he and Dr. 0. R. Langworthy, associate in neurology at
the Medical School, have been coilducting for the past few years.
Fat Rats Withstand Shock

Professor Kouwenhoven has
found that fat animals seem to be
more capable of withstanding electric charges. He attributes this to
the fact that there is less current
concentrated in plump animals and
not because of the resistance of the
fat.
Many scientific papers and monographs have been written on this
topic by the assistant dean.

Today marks the opening of the
third annual campaign of the Hopkins Y. M. C. A. to raise $1200
from the student body at the University. An organization of fiftythree men was formed last night on
the same order as those used in the
past two successful campaigns, with
Walter A. Glass as generalissimo.
The Hopkins Association's budget calls for $1825 to cover expenses
directly traceable to the use of Levering Hall by students and including such items as operating expenses of the Hall, radio repairs, maintenance of the rooming bureau, publication of the Handbook, and similar things. Six hundred and twenty-five dollars of this is covered
by the Y's share of the Student Activities funds. The remainder must
be raised by the students.

Overseas Institute
Announces Offer Of
25 Full Scholarships
serving Students
Announcement has recently been
made by the Overseas Educational
Institute of Hanover, N. H., of
twenty-five full scholarships that it
is offering to deserving students for
study in France, Germany, and in
Switzerland.
A new development in modern
educational organization is revealed
in the program of the Institute, a
school which, in addition to preparing for junior college and college
entrance requirements, presents the
opportunity of travel and association
with European universities and the
cultural advantages to be derived
therefrom.
Visits France And Germany

The institute provides its entire
year's program of travel and study
abroad at a cost approximating an
average year at a prepartory school
or college, and through the medium
of an experienced faculty, offers a
high standard of scholarship.

Council's Duties

Aim At Better June Week;
Suggestions
Wanted
June Week activities made a definite start yesterday when Jack Henderson chairman, appointed Jerome
Toohey, president of the Cotillion
Board; Charles Davis, business
manager of both The Hullabaloo
and the Barnstormers; and Caleb
Kelly, president of the last year's
Junior Class and 1931-32 basketball
captain, to the June Week Committee for this year. These men, at
the request of William Reid, president of the Senior Class, are to prepare a budget for the Week. Reid,
it was announced, will be an exofficio member of the committee.
Hopes To Give Fine Week

"Other men may be appointed at
a later date if the need for more
members becomes apparent," Henderson said yesterday. "I hope,
too, to give Hopkins the finest Julie
Week it has ever had with a material reduction in the cost of tickets.
Any suggestions for the betterment
of June Week, any new events or
changes in the program that will aid
in making it a bigger and better
event will certainly be welcomed by
the committee."
In regard to the additional member of the committee, Henderson
pointed out, a member of the Junior
Class is to be appointed soon by the
president of the Class, Don Kelly,
and that it has been a custom in past
years to select a member of the Cotillion Board to fill that place.

Candidates Turn Out

Few Upsets

Hopkins Swimmi-,g- team thirty-one
candidates turned out. The purpose
of the gathering was to discuss the
plans for the coming year.
Among those back from last year
are Captain William Reid, holder
of the Indoor and Outdoor South
Atlantic Low Board Diving Championship; Edward Sadtler, Johns
Hopkins breast stroke champion;
Ted Stern, Nicholas Camara-Peon,
Charles Bahlke, and Arthur Denues.
All students interested in swimming are urged to come out for the
team.

Running true to form, the favorites have advanced without any major upset. The closest to an upset
was the Needle-Tillman match.
Needle, seeded fourth, finally won,
after three gruelling sets, 8-6, 3-6,
6-2.
The default of Victor Lebow,
seeded third, to D. E. Cohen removes one of the most potent racquet wielders from the field.
With good weather, the latter
part of the week should find some
classy tennis as the late rounds get
under progress.

Mount Washington, and Forest
Park. These clubs, along with
Walbrook, champions last season,
formed the Iceland Hockey League
which operated at Carlin's Rink the
previous year.
The new organization will play
its games at a new rink, the Sports
Centre, which is being erected at
North Avenue and Charles Street.
Mr. Gresham Poe has been elected
president of the new league, and
will control all operations for the
coming season.
The new Sports Centre is located
in the same building where ice
hockey was introduced into this section of the United States several
years ago. It is a striking coincidence that this same building should
be the scene of present-day and improved ice hockey matches.

Cross Country Team
Practices At St. Johns
The cross-country varsity, including Holzman, Packard, Furst, King,
Lewis, Clark, Brown, Emmert, and
Cornman, travelled down to Annapolis on Monday, November 7,
to acquaint themselves with the St.
John's course.
This year the encounter with St.
John's will be especially interesting
because the last two meets were
each decided by a difference of one
point in the score. Furthermore,
a new system of scoring is to be put
into effect for the first time this
year in the St. John's meet by which
men who come in sixth and seventh
influence the count for their team.
The junior varsity meets Poly at
Homewood on Wednesday for its
second meet of the season. The
men who will run are Fryer, Onderdonk, Milstone, Loiseaux, Miller, Emmert, Larrick, and Davies.
